captions.text: MAN ON THE TRACKS

screenplay
based on the short story by
camera
design
director

Who’s joined us?
Tickets, please.
Are we delayed, conductor?

Not at the moment, but the line is being
upgraded to electric traction from Lemiesze on.
Thank you.
Enough, Leszek, you’ll overdo it!
Now two kilometres downhill.

What a ride!
I wish the old man could see it.

On this kind of coal
15 atmospheres.
10.15 p.m., it’ll soon be Lemiesze.

They finished with
the platforms, didn’t they?

- Podany!
- Single light, we can drive fast!
Stasiek, brake!

The engine driver went mad!
Suitcases are falling on our heads!

- What happened?
- Man on the tracks!
Orzechowski!
Look at the semaphore!
Where is the second light?

Yes, yes. At this speed it could
have ended with a major rail crash.

Many people would have died.
The engine driver saw only

- a single lamp.
- I don’t get it.
Right, you’re not a railwayman.

I’ll explain everything,
comrade Karaś.

The switch tower gave a signal –
track free proceed with limited speed.

It means that both arms of
the semaphore were raised
and two green lights are lit.

When an engine driver sees
the signal he must slow down,
or the train will derail at a switch.

And yet there was only one
lamp lit up and this means:

free tracks ahead
no need to slow down.

He lowered the arm and extinguished
the other lamp to cause a rail crash,
do you follow?

- Who lowered the lamp?
- Orzechowski.

And has anyone caught
him red-handed?

Just a moment, so you’re
accusing an old engine driver...

- Of sabotage!
- Orzechowski had an axe to grind

- against the railways.
- Do you see it?
I can’t see anything yet.

He extinguished the light
to derail the train,

and right after that he threw
himself in front of the engine?

I think that one needs to examine
the facts well before making accusations,

- colleague Warda.
- Right, that is what we’re here for.

I propose the representative of the provincial
committee of the communist party
comrade Karaś to chair our committee.
As we’re not from the region,

I think that the host should
begin, comrade Tuszka.

Comrades, let me take
you back by a few years.
I knew Orzechowski before the war.
I was an engine driver assistant in
the second grade engine-house Jarosław.

It was there that
I first met Orzechowski.
I had heard of him before

from my colleagues.
They were all madly afraid of him.

- Tuszka.
- Yes, sir?

Engine driver Orzechowski
will temp for Chrzanowski
until he recovers.
He treated his assistants like servants.

No matter how well one prepared the engine,
he always found something wrong.

Naturally, he found fault
with me as well.

What is it?!
Nuts are not tightened properly!
You’re going to lose bearings!

He was clearly crazy
about bearings.
I didn’t want to quarrel with him.

I was afraid he’d rat on me to
the dispatcher or the stationmaster.
He could be dangerous.

In the steam locomotive
he behaved like a count.

He kept on finding
fault with everything.
If he ever spoke it was to insult.

It’s dirty! You were
spoiled by your engine driver.

He commanded not with
words but with gestures.
For example to switch on the water.

His assistant was expected
to keep silent and work.

He would not let one rest
throughout the trip.

Fortunately, I did not
work with him for long.

- He taught you a lesson, didn’t he?
- He did indeed.

- I remember him well.
- It was customary those days.

- He could have changed.
- Such people don’t change.

There are no people that
never change, stationmaster.
Anyway, listen on.

Last autumn I came
to this roundhouse.

Comrades, things were
going very wrong here.

Everything went ahead as if
of its own momentum.

I received very clear orders –
to introduce a new style of work.

I was to teach people
how to save coal,

cut down the amount of repairs,
increase mileage.
You know.

When you stay here for longer,
you will see it for yourself, stationmaster.

New things don’t catch on
quickly here.
Province.
Whose steam locomotive is this?

This one?
Orzechowski’s.

You may try to convince him
for a long time, stationmaster.
Orzechowski?
Just a moment...

Jankowski!
Come here right away.
Touch it here.

- It’s hot, sir.
- Hot!
You burned the bearings, you idiot.

I will teach to look
after a locomotive.

Orzechowski is a good specialist.
He can see through a steam engine.
He won’t miss anything.

Good old school, from
the Warsaw-Vienna Railways.

- But he doesn’t save coal.
- Well, he doesn’t.

- He won’t touch the locomotive himself.
- Mr Grotowski.
I have work for you.

These fools have not learned
how to look after a steam engine.

- OK.
- Can you spare me a moment?
Naturally.

My name is Tuszka.
We’ve met before, by the way.
I don’ recall.

Anyway, I don’t mean
to talk about the old days.

I was told you know your
engine through and through.

And yet you’re one of
the worst as far as

saving coal is concerned.
Why is it so?

- I drive as I always have.
- Exactly.

Can’t you see what is
going on around you?
The times have changed.

In the best interest of the society
as well as your own you should...
I burn as much coal as I need.

And there is a workshop for repairs.
I arrive punctually.

Has anyone complained?
Maybe the boys?

No, they’re afraid and it’s wrong,
you should end this drill.
I teach as I was taught.

Once they would have to work
for eight years as assistants,

- or even longer.
- Once, once...

Just a moment.
Now I remember.

- We used to work together once.
- It’s not the point, driver.

You should finally understand
what we expect of you.
I do understand.
Goodbye, stationmaster.

After this talk I decided
to watch Orzechowski closely.

I suspected that he kept his
locomotive in the workshop

for so long on purpose,
only in order to spite me.

Jankowski!
Jankowski!

Jankowski!
Where is your driver?

- He’s just left.
- You’re going to miss your turn.

You go to the workshop
with no good reason.

- The driver told me to.
- The driver, the driver...
You’re wasting your own money.
One must listen to the driver.
I noticed that Orzechowski avoided me.
I couldn’t find him anywhere.

Furthermore, I was getting
more and more certain,

that he was turning
people against me.

That day I decided to replace
Orzechowski’s assistant.
And to break his team apart.

I waited until late at night
for the return of his engine.

It should have been done
from the very beginning.

I was afraid Orzechowski would not
get on well with Stasiek Zapora,

an active member of the Communist Youth
organisation whom I could fully trust.
Your bag.
Good evening.
Good evening.

Are you satisfied with
the new assistant?

Thank you.
I’ll teach him everything.

- Goodnight.
- Goodnight.
Zapora!
How was your first trip?

Not too well, there were delays and
we didn’t save much.
It’s bad.
I’m doing all I can.
It should be better next time.

Remember, Zapora,
I am counting on you.
And don’t be afraid of the driver.
A month later we began the action of
introducing all the engine teams
to labour competition.
Orzechowski as usual stirred people.
Remember, comrades,
tomorrow we meet in the new club.
OK, we’ll be there.

And I can see that things
change for the better, comrades.

It’s hard, it’s slow,
but it’s happening.
Our meeting  today

should be a new step
on the way to this goal.

Let’s remember that there are
among us people who don’t understand
what is in their best interest.

By wasting coal you rob
yourselves twice.
First – because you earn less.

And then again – because you
make our common good,
People’s Poland poorer!

Comrades, please, what
are your commitments.
Courage, comrades!
There is nothing to ponder upon.
My team will sign the commitment
to use coal of inferior quality.
Now, it should speed up.

Me and Nowak, we’re ready
to sign such a commitment.

And we call upon
our driver, Orzechowski.

He is good, if he wants to,
he can save a lot of coal.

- I’m not signing anything!
- Haven’t I told you...
Haven’t I told you...

Władek!
Orzechowski, come back!

- Władek!
- What a rascal.

So what now,
wasn’t I right, secretary?

Quiet! Quiet, please!
Sit down, comrades!
We have just witnessed behaviour

which has tarnished the good
name of Polish railwaymen.

I’d like to thank comrade Krokus
for his commitment.

- Do you want to see me?
- I do.
Come in.
No, no, I’ll deal with it myself.

Finally, you found
the way to my office.
Please, sit down.

Well, you have just
betrayed who you are.
In front of everybody.

And we are not going to tolerate this
open hostility, do you understand?

I am responsible
for this roundhouse.
It’s 1950, driver Orzechowski.
I know what year it is, stationmaster.
I won’t have it any longer!

Either you take away that
Zapora of yours from my engine,

- or I am going!
- Why, Mr Orzechowski?
I don’t want your spies in my engine!

- Mr Tuszka!
- Spies?
Yes, I am of the same opinion.
It will be better if you retire.
What?

- Retire? From the railways?
- From the engine.
Your nerves are no longer in order.
Yes, I see.
Orzechowski!
He never came to the roundhouse again.
Just a moment, we’ll ask you.
They said he was taken ill.

He allegedly had suffered from sciatica
but he had kept it secret,

so that we would let him
go on with his work.

He made an official complaint to
the director and I received an enquiry.

But I wrote down the facts,
as I have just presented them,
and I was proven right.

- He was a vermin, comrades.
- Well.
Blind vermin.

I wouldn’t be surprised to find
that he extinguished the light

- on the semaphore.
- Surely.

When he still worked in the roundhouse,
he organised resistance

- against the stationmaster.
- I know nothing about it.
And the chats in the distant corners?

Well, people can chat about anything,
weather for example.

Weren’t there some cases
of sabotage, comrade Tuszka?
Well, yes, there were some.
Someone put sand in bearings.

- Of the outstanding teams?
- Yes.
We failed to find the culprits.

But now you can’t have any
doubts as to whose job it was.
Well...
Excuse me for a moment.
Tuszka.

No, I can’t at the moment.
Take the OKl engine, it’s ready.

I’m certain it is,
I checked it myself.
Yes.

Excuse me, so many things to deal with
and everyone comes to me.
But Orzechowski did not?

- No.
- And Zapora never complained,

- is it true?
- No,
his ambition would not let him.

Maybe Orzechowski also had
his ambition, stationmaster.

I did everything as my
 conscience told me.
Apparently, it is not much.

Maybe you should
have gone to them

if they were not coming
of their own accord.

See what was going
on in this engine.

You were quick to sack a man
after 40 years of work.

There are the facts,
comrade Konarski.

In my opinion, Orzechowski
could not be tolerated.

The stationmaster is
not a holy man.
Now the whole thing is clear to me.

Orzechowski wanted to take revenge on
the stationmaster and the railways.

He extinguished the lamp to kill Zapora
and destroy the engine.

I have worked on the railways
20 years longer than you have, Warda.
He couldn’t do it.

He would break a law
that no one dares to break.
He died under this engine.

I guess, in the very last moment
he understood what he was doing.
How else can you explain it?

Someone else could have
extinguished the light,
and Orzechowski caught him.

And that someone pushed him
under the steam engine.

It’s a good idea
for a detective novel.

Just a moment,
we don’t know everything yet.

Let’s listen to what
Zapora has to say.

- Shall I call him?
- Please, do.
Zapora!
Please.
I’m all ears.

We would like to hear something
from you, colleague.
Tell us, how it went with Orzechowski.
I’ve had enough.

I’d like to ask you, stationmaster,
to transfer me to another roundhouse.

I don’t want to be around
for one day more.

- Why?
- Because of Orzechowski.
Will you transfer me, stationmaster?
We’ll talk about it later.

Tonight Orzechowski was
killed by the engine
which you drove.
Tell us everything you know.
I didn’t do it on purpose!

Well, if I am to tell, I will tell
it all from the beginning.
I joined the railways four years ago.
That was in 1946.

My father did not come back from the
concentration camp and I was left alone.
I had to make a living somehow.
I tried going to the west to steal
but I just didn’t get lucky.
This time it was about a ticket.
Where are you going, bloody fool?

Can’t you see we
have antiquities here?

It was stationmaster Tuszka
who helped me.

- Why are you after this boy?
- It was thanks to him that

I was employed at the railways.
He found me a place in the workshop.

I started to like it.
I stayed.
When he became the stationmaster
I was already in a steam engine team.

- Who did you drive with?
- Engine driver Krokus.
And earlier on with driver Głodek
But it was a small engine.

He taught me to drive and
he would let me drive his small engine
whenever I wanted to.

But by then I missed
the real big steam engines.

- Crazy!
- You’ll break this baby into pieces!

- Zapora!
- Present.
Come here!
You’re moving on to PT-47.

- Really?
- Yes.

- To whom?
- Orzechowski.

There is a vacancy because
Jankowski moved on.
He was promoted to driver.
Remember, it is a serious obligation.

Orzechowski’s team
is one of the worst.
Oh, well, I’ll manage.

I worry about driver Krokus.
We made a good team.
Pity. You have to move on, Zapora.

We have some problems
with Orzechowski and your job
is to keep the team up to speed.
All the best.
I won’t let you down, stationmaster.
I swear I won’t!
The old guy sniffs at the bearings.
Watch out, man, it’s his hobby.
What I am to watch out for?

I have never seen anyone
like your driver.
Our driver, pal.
Good morning, Mr Driver.

- My name is Zapora.
- Good morning.

- Have you been working long with engines?
- It’s my third year.

You’d like to get promoted
to driver soon, wouldn’t you?
Why not?
It seems to be the fashion now.

Do you happen to know
how long I waited?

Twelve years. Or maybe the stationmaster
promised you such a promotion?

Hey, he asks you to
switch on the water.
Ready!
Departure!
Why do you start so rapidly?
We may lose the carriages this way.
Have I asked you anything?

In my team the assistant is
to keep silent and work!

Remember that even your
stationmaster won’t protect you here,
because here I am the driver.
I can defend myself.

Zapora!
Coupling rod is heating up!

- Have you added oil?
- Certainly,

- before we set off.
- Add some more.

He wants to kick you
out of the engine.

- Where to?
- Water.
Make steam!
Zapora! Air pump is jammed.
You didn’t check it.

One can check it a hundred times
and if it is to jam it will get jammed.

There goes your punctuality.
At least five minutes.
Slow down a little, driver,

- I will set it right without stopping.
- Oh, yes.

You’ll fall and I will
have to go to court.
Stay!
Staszek, come on!

I was so afraid!
About you!

Next time check the pump
before departure.

The soup is coming.
My queen, I am starving.

Oh, give it here, my dear,
Give it here.
Bread.
Here you are.

- Good evening.
- Tasty soup.
Yes, yes.
Good evening.
Franek!

Władek! You haven’t
changed a bit.

Władek Orzechowski,
the same as always.
Sit down.

We are only missing
driver Jarząbek
Oh, he’s already six feet under.

He was a hard man but still
he could not resist the time.

But he taught his skill well.
A real master.
There are none left like him.
And his old age pension was different.

This is what we must expect.
Time.
Some time.
Worse comes to worse some kid won’t like you.
This are the times we have.
And how is your family?
I remember Zosia as a little girl.

- You don’t know anything?
- No.
She graduated before the war.
Now she is a doctor in Łódź.

Talented.
Everybody praises her.

And she earns well.
She always wants to assist me.

You don’t need any assistance,
I guess.
I don’t intend to kill myself.

For a handful of money
like some little boy.

I won’t burn stones
in my steam engine.

Wait, you got promoted to
driver in 1914, didn’t you?
Yes. A week before Sarajevo.
I was so jealous of you then, pal.
I got stone drunk in my misery.

- I remember, I drove the cab back home.
- Well.

I paid the cabbie one rouble.
One silver rouble.

I climbed the stairs like a pig,
on all fours.

And my wife was seven
months pregnant.

- Oh, good old days.
- Yes, yes.

Come, Franek,
we must have a chat.
I’ll help you with that, Miss Halinka.

- Thank you, there’s no need.
- No, no, it’s better to do it together.
Was that your old companion?

We worked five years together
on the Warsaw-Vienna Railways.

- With driver Jarząbek?
- With driver Jarząbek.
Thank you for switching off the light.
Pick up the hat, one of you two.
There are no servants in an engine.
Get out!
But how?

I said!
Get out!
I can make do without you!

- The old guy went mad.
- Run for home.
I will stay here a little longer.

Hi, driver!
Is there something for me to do?
No! I can manage myself.
It’s OK then.

- Mr driver, what is it?
- I’m fine.
Go away. Do you hear me?
Staszek!

- Good morning.
- Good morning.
Good morning, Mr Driver.

Ah, good morning.
This is Zapora.
Nice to meet you.
Please, sit down.

No, thank you,
we’re going to the movies.

Ah, the movies.
Good bye.
Have fun.

Come on, go, or the train
will depart without you.
Good bye.

Bye, bye.
Come on, go now.

Just imagine, bro, that
just yesterday, you see, I met

in the dance hall
this girl, you know.
I am holding a place for you.
2500, I can’t give any more.
My own cost is more or less 3000.
Throw in 500 and we’re good.

- May I?
- Thank you very much.
<i>Attention! Attention!</i>

<i>Express train from
Wrocław to Gdynia...</i>

The queue to buy sausages
was too long, I didn’t make it.
Well.

Should I leave the engine
and wait in the queue?
Is it my fault?
You can only talk.
<i>Workers of the world, unite!</i>

<i>Potato beetle, farmer is...
Farmer, potato beetle is your enemy!</i>

<i>Exceeding the goals
of the 6-year plan,</i>

<i>we improve our quality of life.
Mother, protect your child</i>
<i>from diarrhoea.</i>
Depart!
2000 each, I can’t give more.
Are you mad? 2500.

- I will add another 100.
- No, I can’t.

- Well, that’s better.
- So write.
Faster, the train is departing.
Hold it.
Run. Stay safe!
Steam!
But I’m pouring!

No this way, pour to the sides, then you
can make steam even with this kind of coal.

You would probably manage
to drive on shit.

- Closed!
- Closed!
Shit, 15 minutes late.

We would need St Cecilia
to stand you, driver.

Have I asked you
anything, asshole?

You can call your own
kids assholes, driver!

You don’t deserve to compare
yourself to my child!

Once I would have dealt
with you summarily!
The days of driver Jarząbek are gone!
They’re gone? Really?
Driver, we can go!
Maybe I can make more money,

but we don’t feel like making
any such commitments,
am I right, Orzechowski?

Well, Orzechowski is not
willing to make such deals.

Shouldn’t we think
every now and then?

What do you mean - think?
What are you talking about, Władek?

What you’ve just heard.
It’s not a problem to

keep on repeating the same thing
over and over again. Sometimes...
Remember, comrades,
tomorrow we meet in the new club.
OK, we’ll be there.

And I can see that things
change for the better, comrades.

It’s hard, it’s slow,
but it’s happening.
Our meeting  today

should be a new step
on the way to this goal.

Let’s remember that there are
among us people

- who don’t understand...
- Now you can have your way

with the old man.
Just say what happened.

Shut up.
This is between him and me.
Wasting coal

- Look at Głodek.
- you rob yourselves twice
First – because you earn less.

And then again – because you
make our common good,
People’s Poland poorer!

Comrades, please, what
are your commitments.
They may wait for us.
Courage, comrades!
here is nothing to ponder upon.
My team will sign the commitment
to use coal of inferior quality.

Me and Nowak, we’re ready
to sign such a commitment.

And we call upon
our driver, Orzechowski.
He is good, if he wants to,
he can save a lot of coal.

Just look, your assistant
rules in your team.
I’m not signing anything!

Orzechowski!
Władek!

- Władek! Come back!
- Mr Głodek.

Quiet! Quiet, please!
Sit down, comrades!
We have just witnessed behaviour

which tarnishes the good
name of Polish railwaymen.

I’d like to thank comrade Krokus
for his commitment.

- Where is Orzechowski?
- With the stationmaster.

The old man made
a mess, didn’t he?
Look, he’s coming.
Władek, listen...

- What it with him?
- It all starts again.

Man hardly has
enough patience.
Who lacks patience?!

You had it your way
with Tuszka, you scoundrel!

- You wanted to be promoted to driver, didn’t you?
- Władek!
I will show you, you scoundrel!
You bloody kid!

- I will show you!
- Calm down, Władek!

- Calm down!
- I will show you...

- What is going on here?!
- Władek.

- I will show you, you...
- What is this supposed to mean?!

- We’re going!
- Just a moment.

You can’t drive
the engine so agitated.

Someone from the reserve
will take over.

Stationmaster, he is
not coming back, is he?
No.
And this is all.
A month later I took his place.

People would say that
I kicked him out of the engine.
And yesterday the worst happened.

I don’t want to be here any longer.
Transfer me, stationmaster.

Why didn’t you report
the scuffle on the engine?
I understand him.

Anyway now we know what
kind of person Orzechowski was,

what he did on his engine,
colleague Konarski.

And we know that he did not urge
anyone to sabotage, colleague Warda.
There is still Sałata.

- The level crossing attendant?
- Yes.
He is responsible for the semaphore.

He was arrested immediately
after the accident.
Call him, stationmaster.

Unfortunately, the stationmaster
failed to mention that
he immediately fired Orzechowski.
On the spot.

Orzechowski was a blockhead
and a vindictive one as well.

- He extinguished the lamp.
- And immediately jumped in front of the train?

You have just said someone
might have pushed him.
Level crossing attendant Sałata.
Take a seat.
You know why we called you.
I don’t know.
I don’t know anything.

I wanted to ask you
why you arrest
an innocent man.
What have I done?
I work well.

The stationmaster Tuszka
may confirm it.
He has known me for many years.

This is for the public
prosecutor to decide.
We’re interested in something else.
Did you see Orzechowski yesterday?
I did.

- He came to me.
- How did he behave?

- Ordinarily.
- What do you mean, ordinarily?

Well... ordinarily,
as usual.
Do you know how he died?

- I do.
- How did it happen?

- Ordinarily, he jumped and it was over.
- For you everything is ordinary,

- also how a man dies?
- So you could have pushed him
under an engine, couldn’t you?

Me? Him?
Jesus!
It’s not true!

Only you were with him
in the moment of his death.

No!
I was not.

He jumped by the semaphore,
and I stayed by my box.

- Mr Zapora can be a witness.
- I don’t remember where Sałata was.
I ran without looking at anyone.
How?

Mr Zapora, I screamed
from the box: what happened?

I don’t remember.
There were many people screaming.

Why would I throw him
under the engine?

He noticed that you
extinguished the lamp.

- Lamp? What lamp?
- Stop playing a fool!

You had extinguished one lamp
before the train arrived.

It’s impossible!
Listen! It’s not true!

I went to the semaphore
last time before dusk.

I pulled up both.
They were lit up.
It was Orzechowski!

How do you know
it was Orzechowski?
Because he went mad.

When the stationmaster
kicked him out...
I mean, when he let him retire,

the very first day he got drunk,
I remember it clearly.

I was just closing the crossing
when I saw him.

I was surprised because at this hour
he should have been near Poznań.

I saw it immediately
that he was drunk.

- How did you know?
- Because he could hardly stand.
Wicek, lower the barrier.

- I don’t feel well.
- You should have left it at the station.

- I would bring it.
- Once I waited for two days.
Good evening, driver.
Why isn’t Franka at school?

You’ll starve the children
to death, lazybones.
Good evening, driver.
I have fresh butter and veal.

Even Zosia, I mean my wife,
was surprised,
that he was so drunk at noon.

And when he passed the box
the train passed by

and the driver fell down
because of the gust of air.

Fortunately, he did not fall
in front of the train.
But God is kind to drunks.

I ran to help him up and, as
I have  a very keen sense of smell,

I knew immediately
that it was vodka.
It is not true!

Driver Orzechowski
never drank vodka.

Wasn’t he offered vodka many a time?
And that day right after the meeting

he boarded the train
and went home.
People saw him at the station.

Well, you seem to
be fibbing, Mr Sałata.
I’m not fibbing.
I know nothing about any lamp.

He extinguished it!
It must have been him.
I never left the crossing.
Mr Stationmaster will confirm.

OK, OK. You better tell us what
happened with Orzechowski.

- Had you known him for long?
- Certainly, he was a neighbour.
And a close person.
I visited him every now and then.
Good afternoon, driver.

- Good afternoon.
- I brought some meat.

- You seem sick.
- No! Not sick, not sick.
Now that I have dropped by

I’d like to remind you about
the job that I enquired after.

I am not going to
the roundhouse for a while.

- What do you mean: for a while?
- I won’t let them oust me!
I won’t let them!
I won’t!

Are they going to ask
your permission, Mr Orzechowski?

You must not disturb
my husband, Mr Sałata.
I’m going.
Good bye, Mr Driver.
I consoled him as I could.
But he was in a foul mood.
Worse every day.

He was drying up like
a fish without water.

And his mind was not
in the best order.

It’s a lie, don’t make
a lunatic out of him.

The doctor diagnosed him
with strong agitation.
Sometimes it’s hard to tell.

You’d rather make a lunatic
out of him, colleague Konarski?
Come in.
Thank you.

And how was it yesterday,
colleague Sałata?
It was a day full of misfortunes.

Man has gotten used to the fact
that evil comes from every direction.

Yes, yes. Patient must be
taken to the hospital.

- Surgery is imminent.
- Zosia.
What is it?

I’m really sick.
I’m not going to make it.

- Where are the goods?
- In the guardroom.

Take the basket.
Wicek, kids.
Remember, don’t oversleep.
We’ll take you to the train.

I have already called
for an ambulance.
Zosia.
Faster, faster!

- Wicek, remember, the kids!
- All aboard!

Give me back the button!
Come, give me the button!

- Dad, she is pulling at my hair!
- She took my button!

- Go back home! Home!
- Button! Button!

- Home! Be quiet!
- Shit!

Mr Driver?
Where are you going?

- To the station.
- So late?

Why did your wife let
you out of the house.

- I have to go.
- You will, driver, you will.
But not now.
There is no train right now.
You better come to my place.
You’ve aged, driver.

I understand it,
people kicked me around too.
You did it too, driver.
You passed by, hardly looking.

And did you know what
was going on inside me?
OK.
Now we’re in the same boat.

Will you drink, driver,
to this lousy life?

No, no, no.
I never drink when I’m on duty.
What duty? Are you mad?
They forced you to retire, driver.
Go and let the train pass.

It’s your engine, driver,
with that Zapora.
Maybe you’ll try to jump aboard?

- What happened?
- Man on the tracks!

The engine driver went mad!
Suitcases are falling on our heads!
So what now, colleague Konarski?
I don’t know.
And if Orzechowski did not jump?
Would you slow down, Zapora?
No.

The train would derail
at the points.
I don’t want to think about it.
Do you smoke?
I don’t understand.
I just asked if you smoked.

Oh yes!
I mean, not on duty.
Do you have light?
Don’t have matches on you?
No, I got used to the lighter.

Although some people say
it’s more expensive now.

And you’re sure you did not
approach the semaphore?
I swear!

I have an interesting piece
of information, comrades.

Orzechowski’s watch was
found between the tracks.

And by the semaphore a box
and eight burned matches.

There was no kerosene
in the lowered lamp.
It means that Orzechowski...
Just a moment.

Let me tell how I see
what happened.

After his chat with Sałata
Orzechowski ran out of the box.
We know that he was agitated.

He did not pay attention to
what was going on around him.

But he certainly noticed
what every true
railwayman had to notice,

that one lamp on
the semaphore was not lit up.
It’s stuffy here.
THE END

comments.author: listonoszpat233

comments.text:
Można debatować co można było..., tak jak w przypadku każdej prawdziwej 
katastrofy. W niejednej nie zdołano dojść do tego dlaczego ktoś postąpił 
tak, a nie inaczej. Racjonalnie owszem mógł podawać drugą lampą sygnał 
stój, ale ludzie w sytuacjach stresowych nie działają racjonalnie. Tak jak 
i w przypadku Orzechowskiego, wobec którego w filmie padają słowa: Lekarz 
stwierdził stan silnego podniecenia(czyt. stresu). Orzechowski postąpił nie 
racjonalnie, ale chwalebnie, bo jak kol wiek by nie oceniać jego 
poświęcenia, czy po prostu zachowania, doprowadził do pożądanego skutku, 
zatrzymał pociąg, uchronił przed katastrofą.
  Kolejną kwestią jest to dlaczego nikt z służby drogowej nie zauważył 
zgaśnięcia lampy semafora? Przecież istnieje sygnał kontrolny(białe światło 
z tyłu semafora). Dyżurny podając wolną drogę powinien go sprawdzić... Cóż 
jak w każdym wypadku tak zwany splot niefortunnych zdarzeń.
   Niemniej jednak, czy jest sens je rozważać? To jest ekranizacja dzieła 
literackie, w którym nie chodziło o mechanika, czy wypadek, a o zderzenie 
przedwojennego z socjalistycznym. Młodego ze starym o czasy stalinowskie, 
gdzie doszukiwano się wszędzie spiskowców...
    Film jest znakomity, zarówno ze względu na to, że jest nowatorski jak 
na swoje czasy, ma znakomicie budowane napięcie. Retrospekcje, znaną z dużo 
późniejszego kina Pana Tarantino.... Wykorzystanie dynamiki maszyn i ujęć, 
świetna gra aktorska mi. Opalińskiego. Opaliński po tych filmach(CnT oraz 
Droga na zachód, był maszynistą z zamiłowania, mało kto wie, że był z tego 
dumny i od czasu do czasu prowadził normalne pociągi...)
Kolejna rzecz, godna uwagi, to to, że tak jak w kolejarskim słowie jest 
fantastyczna muzyka Jana Krenza(późniejszego dyrektora muzycznego 
filharmonii monachijskiej) i tylko kilka odgłosów maszyn, tak w tym filmie 
nie ma grama muzyki, wszędzie są idealnie podłożone dźwięki maszyn, pracy i 
ludzi... a przy tym przerwy w dialogach nie są jałowe...
Ponad to film jest ponad czasowy! Uchwyca piękno kolei, stereotyp 
przedwojennego kolejarza. Relacje, dume i ambicje, napięcia między ludźmi o 
silnym charakterze. Jednocześnie to za co my go kochamy: zwraca szacunek do 
kolejarza i pokazuje jak można szanować, kochać swoją pracę. Być sumiennym 
dobrym fachowcem....
comments.author: Maurycy K-M
